attributes.title: In the begining
attributes.description:
A plain ordinary talking octopus, was having a seemingly ordinary day, with his good friend the local mantee Berine. This name was given to the manatee by a girl named Suzin. She had received his ownership as a birthday present from her parents, who wanted to do something good for the enviorment, without personally having anything to do with it.


The two sea creatures were paying a game they developed called barnicle ride. Consisting of the octopus clinging on to Bernie, so that he could experience the life of a manatee first hand.

attributes.title: "Bernie is dead."
attributes.description:
"There was a lot of blood." The octopus thought. "where should I go from here? I don't want to swim in that mess. I am alone now. I can't go back to the sea. I can only go forward. For Bernie I will find out more of the world that it has allowed." His tentacles stung and his heart shook with overwhelming loss.

"Are you alright?" The two fishermen stood over him shaking him back into reality.

"I will be fine, I think. Just if you could please take me to the land." The seven legged octopus said looking towards a new place with unfamiliar inhabitants, new experiences and new possibilities.

attributes.title: "Whats next?"
attributes.description: The septopus asked himself while experiencing his new weight for the first time. The air was lighter than water, but he moved slowly, deep in thought, pulled down by the oppressive force of gravity. "I felt like so much more of an octopus only a little while ago. I need to find where I am, and where I'm going. There must be more to this world for me. I will find it, but where to start?" His mind began to feel fluttery, too full of new ideas and questions of this strange new environment. "Well here seems as good a place to start as anywhere." He sat and waited pondering a sign advertising public transportation.

attributes.title: Waiting led itself to thinking, and thinking was not his leisure.
attributes.description:
The bus took too long to show up. 

“It has been a long day already,” he stared towards the
sky in awe over what has happened “and many bad
things happened to me. To make two new friends in
a fatal accident doesn’t make up for the one I’ve lost.”
He pulled at sign releasing it to watch it vibrate in the
daylight sun.

“And what of this land thing. My tentacles are stuck to
it. I can’t swim up any further, maybe this is as high as
it gets, or perhaps I have just always been in the middle and its all relative. Or maybe the top is the bottom, the outside is the inside, the middle the crust and all of everything overlaps itself in some quantum infante reality.” This was all very confusing for him and caused a terrible headache. “At least, this section of quantum reality has public transportation. I don’t even need to walk to get places because of this wonderful idea. It must truly save the common man time, aggravation, and effort.” At that
time the bus arrived.

attributes.title: Suddenly, pain shot from his tentacle to his brain and back to his tentacle.
attributes.description:
This was not like the last time. Last time he was unconscious.

The septapus decided he had to do something. He could not last any longer in this situation. He pulled at his tentacle but it would not budge against the weight of the bus. He decided it was his only option to ask the man inside this machine if he had any idea how to move this automotive monstrosity.

”What the heck are you?” The driver looked on at our trapped horrified hero.

attributes.title: “No change no ride!”
attributes.description:
The bus driver screamed unknowing of the situation at hand. Only realizing the severity of someone breaking the rules.

“It didn’t say that on the sign.” Our hero mumbled choking on his urges to scream.

Trapped to the concrete by his tentacle, under the weight of a bus, the ex-octopus fidgeted at the
controls, hoping to move this heavy thing crushing his appendage, but he only managed to close the door, before getting himself ejected by a bus driver ranting about freeloaders.

attributes.title: The past octopus’ pain subsided and grew in to an overwhelming, immeasurable amount of anger.
attributes.description: “Lousy money grubbing bastards. God, only let me see him again. I’ll give him a little more than 75 cents. Maybe this land business isn’t such a good idea, if its filled with people like that. I would rather be eaten alive at sea than pay that yuppie a nickel.” His mind turned to breaking things, and destroying property. Then he imagined himself waiting at the stop for the bus driver to get back so he could throw his severed tentacle on to the bus. “That would show him something.” He laughed to himself, not a healthy chuckle but a strung out insane laugh in which he immediately stopped. “I’m hungry.” He thought to himself tasting the blood left on one of his remaining intact tentacles, realizing that a new visitor had invaded the personal space of his shattered limb. The creature at hand was small, black, and appeared to be biting at his fallen extremity.

attributes.title: “Who are you, and what are you doing with my tentacle?”
attributes.description:
The sextapus looked on in awe at the audacity of this new comer.

“Well, I am an ant, and with your tentacle, I’m leaving a trail of chemicals so the other ants can come and help me carry it back to the nest for the feast. We need to feed the queen and her armies.” The ant finished and at this the owner of their late lunch decided, that It was about smashy time, when he noticed something new about both the ant and himself.

attributes.title: “Hooray for the new ant!”
attributes.description:
The ants welcomed him in full force flailing there arms, and thanking him for the blessing that will become their dinner.

“I would just like to thank you guys for making me feel like I wasn’t wasting my time with this whole land thing. It’s good to feel like I’m part of something again. Well besides for the food chain.” An ants life felt good to him. He finally found his place.

“Yes, all is good. Follow us friend to our castle, the queen awaits your attendance. She holds much wisdom that she cares to share with you.” On that the ants made there way to the hill that was there castle.

attributes.title: The present owner of the tree was far more than happy to welcome its uninvited dinner guests.
attributes.description: Because for the bird it was dinner time, and the ant came with free delivery, and was not even expecting a tip. In a quarter second the bird snapped down and had the ant in its beak, baring down on its midsection. This bird’s disrespect for his ant brother, the giant ant could not stand for. Upon Finishing his climb he drew in with all of his power and hit the bird towards the stratosphere.

attributes.title: “We have to do something.”
attributes.description:
The ants fell on him like rain, only managing to move small parts of his body before he began to stir. From his lowered angle the ants looked huge and startled him into something that closer that resembled reality. He was taken to the queen who stood waiting for him on top of the hill. 

“I have failed my queen. Not only that but I have lost the guide you have given me.” He felt less than dirt and stood waiting for the consequences. 

“You have not failed. You have just found yourself somewhere that is not for you. You
might not know it but you are more than an ant you are something different, something wonderful and we will find a place for you.” She smiled, spreading her wings glistening in the sun, bent her knees and flew off into the distance.

attributes.title: Upon entering it was even darker than he expected but not as dark as his feelings at this point.
attributes.description: “How could so many bad things happen to one creature in one day. Is it such a dark reality we live in?” He felt sorry for himself and for everyone else that has ever been is such a morbid disposition. “Nothing is right, nothing is holy, our god is either a sham or an evil, sadomasochistic, omnipotent creature, the demented leader of a desolate shatterproof reality.” He continued to walk deeper and deeper thinking until he stumbled into what was next.

attributes.title: The sextapus stumbled and rolled down a hill paved with pointed rocks only to have his fall  stopped by a large fuzzy object.
attributes.description:
“At least there is a pillow in here.” He said to himself before realizing that the pillow was moving and probably about eight feet tall.

The bear was not happy about his disturbed slumber or the intruder’s unlawful trespass. The sex tapus made for the door but was pinned down again by his tentacle. He tugged with all his might, struggling to escape the will of the bear. With a snap from his tenticle he was free, off for the exit with pain shooting behind him like the fire trail from a rocket. The rough ground hurt as his tender extremities slapped upon the pavement. Where there were once tentacles now only a twinge.

attributes.title: “I’m not an octopus, manatee, ant, bird, spider, bus driver, or sleeping comfy pillow."
attributes.description: That really narrows it down. I have no friends, no home and only 5 tentacles. I should have thought about this land thing, before I deceided to leave my ocean.” He trecked forward touching everything. “If I was a bird I could fly, or a whale I would be the master of the sea, I would even take being that pillow, it had some dinner and a spot to rest.” He carried on using his free tentacles to trace their way around walls, searching corners for anything that could help his survival. It was a cold night. Starving, he was running out of energy to go on. The creature walked alone, nearly exhausted, positive that there were predators nearby. Fortunately wandering around a corner, he groped his way into a recessed ally, there noticing something wonderful. A dry cardboard box. “Never has anything been so beautiful.” He whisperd, cautiously creeping towards it, knowing he couldn’t afford any more mistakes. The inside of the box was dark, but with further inspection empty. He looked around silently, touching a tentacle to the top to make sure that it was real. With one more check to make sure nothing spotted, him he excitedly climbed in. “Finally a home to rest in.” The nomadic creature sleepily mumbled and allowed himself rest.

attributes.title: Distress drove the creature on, causing a delirous fervor that overwhelmed his senses.
attributes.description:
Tears wrenched from his eyes. Rubbing left them stinging and dry. He blew past the bus stop, moving beyond the dock stopping for nothing. The ocean’s consistant roar surfaced suffocating memories, that bobbed in the waves. The has-been octopus pushed forward, suddenly halting feeling overtaken by a stifiling tightness. A honeycomb latice of red and brown began to enclose around his pereferal, causing nearby echoes to seem distant. His head spun and his stomach ached. Both hot and cold, the tips of his tentacles twitched intermitently. With a shake from his chest a grumble from his stomach he cryed, “mMm-
Mmmmm...AAAAGGGGghghghghghg!!! What was that things problem?!!”, his breath fell uneven as he swung his remaining tentcles wildly. “Wahhh ddaaaaa Faaaah???. The overhead light silently went dark.

As time passed he thought of nothing. Not his phantom tentacles, nor the insessant pull of gravity persisting his attachemnt to the pavement, nor lights, sounds, smells, or emotion. No thoughts occured. He was elsewhere, floating through the ethers looking at everything and nothing, simply being. Realitys echoes seemed at such a distance they couldn’t exist in this place.

attributes.title: The life of a manatee can be rich but short lived.
attributes.description:
In being a sea baring mammal, manatee occasionally need to come up for air, and because of their slow speed they don't swim very deep. This in order to avoid the possibility of drowning. The boat half keelhauled the pair before the fishermen noticed the differences in angle of the ship.

The younger man threw the live preserver down to the pair. The octopus was saved baring one of his tentacles, but Bernie taking the brunt of the impact fell to his injuries. The shocked octopus, dazed slowly took grasp of what had happened.
